title.narrative: Acción Comunitaria en Pro de la Seguridad Pública

description.narrative: El objetivo de esta operación es mejorar la capacidad del gobierno de Belice de diseñar, ejecutar y monitorear políticas integrales de prevención de la violencia a nivel secundario y terciario. Dichas políticas estarán focalizadas en la juventud de la Ciudad de Belice, grupo estáreo que representa el grueso de las víctimas y victimarios de la violencia y el delito. Las actividades incluirán el diseño y puesta en marcha de programas educacionales y sociales con involucramiento de las organizaciones comunitarias de base, la mejora de los mecanismos interinstitucionales de coordinación, el desarrollo de infraestructuras específicas y la mejora de las estrategias de comunicación social de dichas políticas.

The objective of this operation is to increase Belize's government capacity to design, execute and monitor integral secondary and tertiary violence prevention policies. The activities will be targeted towards Belize¿s city youth, social group that represents most of the victims and perpetrators of violence. They will include the design and implementation of community-based social and educational programs, the improvement of new mechanisms of interinstitutional coordination, the development of dedicated infrastructure, and the improvement of the policies social communication strategies.

activity-description.narrative: As part of an aftercare program, counseling services have been setup for at-risk youth and juvenile offenders. Counselors trained in new methodologies in juvenile rehabilitation and after care are available to provide services. It is expected that every year some 270 youth will access these services, thereby reducing recidivism and the rate of institutionalization of young people.

Hardware and software for the Interagency Public Safety Management Information System (IPSMIS) were installed in the Information Technology Center of the Ministry of the Public Service. IPSMIS is designed to assist the Government of Belize, by using the data currently being updated in the database, to formalize strategies and make policies for effective interventions in the areas of violence and crime prevention.

More than 50 persons were trained as mentors on a curriculum that emphasizes positive youth development, ethical values and civics, civil coexistence and the reduction of violent behavior, promotion of healthy behavior and personal conduct. Mentors will work with students, unattached youths, parents and other community members.

Policy analysts from the various agencies that work with the Interagency Public Safety Management Information System (IPSMIS) were trained in the use of the system. It is expected that they will be able to use the system to generate information for effective decision making by policy makers.

The Community Action for Public Safety (CAPS) project aims to foster community and family participation in children’s lives and create an overall environment for positive development. The Inter-Agency Public Safety Management Information System (IPSMIS) enables national social data to be compiled, analyzed and shared between the agencies responsible for addressing crime and violence. Sixteen inter-agency IT technicians received training in the use of IPSMIS tool.

The Community Action for Public Safety (CAPS) project aims to foster community and family participation in children’s lives and create an overall environment for positive development. The Inter-Agency Public Safety Management Information System (IPSMIS) enables national social data to be compiled, analyzed and shared between the agencies responsible for addressing crime and violence. Sixteen inter-agency policy makers received training in the use of IPSMIS tool.

The Gateway Youth Center was constructed and equipped in August 2014 to provide a facility where youths will receive instructional learning in the classroom and engage in positive extracurricular activities combining sports, music and the arts. It is envisioned that the Gateway Center will be a creative space for young people that will foster constructive use of their time by nurturing their skills and expanding their knowledge in subjects such as Math and English, at the same time, promote an environment for positive behavior and social patterns.

The Positive Youth Development Curriculum has been developed and completed. This curriculum will eventually be implemented at the Gateway Youth Center and at pilot schools in an effort to improve learning and secondary education completion rates, and to foster positive behavior patterns among youth from vulnerable communities. Efforts will be directed at both students and youth who are unemployed and not in school or in training.

The female dormitory at the Youth Hostel was constructed in August 2014 to free up additional space and to avoid overcrowding. Together with other improvements in youth facilities this dormitory is a safe haven that that will encourage better care for those youth at the facilities.

The refurbishment of the basketball court at the Youth Cadet Corps (YCC) was completed in June 2014. It provides much needed space for the youth of the YCC to engage in extracurricular activities. It’s one of the improvements at the YCC that will help in the provision of better care, and foster a creative space for sportsmanship and athletics.

The resource center was constructed on the compound of the Youth Hostel to provide facilities for academic and vocation training classrooms, as well as to free up space in the YCC’s other facilities. Together with other improvements in youth facilities this new construction will help in the provision of better care for those youth at the facilities.

To assist at-risk youth and juvenile offenders, a Care Model has been designed. This model will be implemented at the Youth Cadet Corps, The Youth Hostel, and the Wagner Youth Facility to reduce the rate of recidivism and improve the youth’s possibility of social reintegration. The model is based on international best practices, which highlight the need for an individualized plan for rehabilitation, with a strong emphasis on family and community involvement. The model incorporates the use of an AfterCare Program Manual, A Continuum of Care Manual, and a Substance Abuse Manual.
